metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: When you know exactly how many times you want to loop through a block of code, use the for loop instead of a while loop:
content.html: When you know exactly how many times you want to loop through a block of code, use the for loop instead of a while loop:

content.code_html:
for (statement 1; statement 2; statement 3) {
  // code block to be executed
}

content.text: Statement 1 is executed (one time) before the execution of the code block.
content.html: Statement 1 is executed (one time) before the execution of the code block.

content.text: Statement 2 defines the condition for executing the code block.
content.html: Statement 2 defines the condition for executing the code block.

content.text: Statement 3 is executed (every time) after the code block has been executed.
content.html: Statement 3 is executed (every time) after the code block has been executed.

content.text: The example below will print the numbers 0 to 4:
content.html: The example below will print the numbers 0 to 4:

content.code:
for

(
int
i
=

0
;
i
<

5
;
i
++
)

{


System
.
out
.
println
(
i
)
;


}
content.code_html:
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
  System.out.println(i);
}

content.text: Statement 1 sets a variable before the loop starts (int i = 0).
content.html: Statement 1 sets a variable before the loop starts (int i = 0).

content.text: Statement 2 defines the condition for the loop to run (i must be less than 5). If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if it is false, the loop will end.
content.html: Statement 2 defines the condition for the loop to run (i must be less than 5). If the condition is true, the loop will start over again, if it is false, the loop will end.

content.text: Statement 3 increases a value (i++) each time the code block in the loop has been executed.
content.html: Statement 3 increases a value (i++) each time the code block in the loop has been executed.

content.text: This example will only print even values between 0 and 10:
content.html: This example will only print even values between 0 and 10:

content.code:
for

(
int
i
=

0
;
i
<=

10
;
i
=
i
+

2
)

{


System
.
out
.
println
(
i
)
;


}
content.code_html:
for (int i = 0; i <= 10; i = i + 2) {
  System.out.println(i);
}
